newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu, Arafat hold summit, pledge peace.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu, Arafat hold summit, pledge peace.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat shook hands for the first time on Wednesday promising to pursue Middle East peace together.

The meeting marked the right-wing Israeli leader's formal acceptance of Arafat as a negotiating partner three years after the former guerrilla chief sealed a peace deal with a historic handshake with Yitzhak Rabin on the White House lawn.

But their hour-long summit at the Israel-Gaza border began awkwardly with a brief handshake too quick to photograph and did not resolve a major obstacle delaying the implementation of Palestinian autonomy -- the date and scope of Israel's troop redeployment in the West Bank city of Hebron.

Israeli Defence Minister Yitzhak Mordechai will meet Arafat on Sunday to tackle that issue and discuss Israel's six-month-old closure of the West Bank and Gaza, Netanyahu said in Tel Aviv after the summit.
"The next day, we will convene the (Israeli-Palestinian) steering committees for the first official meeting and we will begin the discussions," the prime minister said.
Although short on substance the meeting and handshake were seen as vital symbols of both sides' commitment to the stalled Oslo peace agreement.

Netanyahu had delayed meeting Arafat, whom he used to brand a "terrorist", citing security concerns. But the Likud prime minister came under strong pressure from the United States, co-sponsor of Middle East peace efforts, to meet the PLO chairman. Netanyahu visits Washington next week.
"I believe that we will work with Mr Bibi (Netanyahu) and his government to push the peace process, the peace of the brave," Arafat said at a post-summit news conference.

"Both parties reiterate their commitment to the interim agreement and their determination to carry out its implementation," Netanyahu said, referring to self-rule deals between the previous Israeli government and the PLO.

But he told the news conference: "We have to take into account the needs and requirements of both sides on the basis of reciprocity and the assurance of the security and well-being of both Israelis and Palestinians alike."
By security, Netanyahu means protection for the 400 Jewish settlers living among more than 100,000 Arabs in Hebron and changes to the troop redeployment set in a 1995 agreement with the PLO.

"We made it clear that with all our good intentions to carry out the agreement, a security underpinning must be added to allow the Jewish population in Hebron to live as normal and safe a life as possible," Netanyahu said in Tel Aviv.

Arafat appeared to be content with the victory Palestinian officials said he achieved by getting a reluctant Netanyahu to meet him, and gave a muted response when asked at the news conference about the Hebron issue.
"I have nothing to add but to state that we will continue to negotiate and to coordinate all efforts, by all means," Arafat said.

"The road is paved for the negotiations between us on all aspects and at every level, including the final-status talks, of course," he said. But Palestinian officials said from their perspective the talks were on implementation rather than changing previous accords.

Israeli and Palestinian negotiators, with the help of Terje Larsen, a U.N. official and Norwegian middleman who helped broker the original Oslo self-rule accord in 1993, struggled in the past week to find a formula for a summit and peace talks.
Netanyahu's agreement to meet Arafat followed some tough talk and strident action from the Palestinian leader.
Arafat said last week's Israeli decision to expand Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza and its policy on Jerusalem were tantamount to declaring war on the Palestinians.
He also called a four-hour general strike in the two areas last Thursday, the first such stoppage in two years.
Netanyahu and Arafat started the meeting at the Israel-Gaza border with a quick handshake that caught photographers off-guard.
They shook hands again -- this time for four seconds -- as cameras clicked but ignored shouted appeals from photographers at the end of their news conference for another replay.
The meeting followed four days of intensive talks to fix a summit seen as vital to reviving peace talks suspended since Islamic suicide bombers killed 59 people in Israel in February and March.
